questions.question: Question 1: What is the lifespan of a platelet?
questions.explanation:
The average lifespan of platelets in circulation is 7–10 days. Thrombopoietin (TPO) is the regulator of platelet production. A reduction in platelet and 
megakaryocyte mass increases the level of TPO, which then stimulates platelet production. The shelf life of donor platelets is 5 days. It is stored on a special agitator at 20-24 °C. The half-life 
of transfused platelets is 3-5 days.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following would you not expect to see in patients with a platelet disorder?
questions.explanation:
Hemarthrosis is highly suggestive of a coagulation disorder, not a platelet disorder. Bleeding diathesis can occur due to: • Platelet disorders - mucocutaneous bleeding like petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses, epistaxis, 
menorrhagia, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeds • Coagulation disorders - hemarthrosis, muscle hematomas, and bleeding into soft tissues • Disorders of the vessel wall (Henoch-Schönlein purpura, scurvy) - purpura and ecchymosis 1352 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is a disorder of platelet adhesion?
questions.explanation:
Bernard Soulier syndrome is a disorder of platelet adhesion. It occurs due to an inherited defect in 
the GPIb-IX complex.

questions.question: Question 4: Patients with which of the following conditions would have a low platelet count?
questions.explanation:
Thrombocytopenia is a feature of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. It is an X-linked recessive condition caused by mutations in the WASP gene. It affects T-cells and 
platelets and presents with the following features: • Eczema 1353 
Sold by @itachibot • Thrombocytopenia - along with decreased platelet size, impaired platelet aggregation response • Immunodeficiency - low IgM, high IgE, defective regulatory T cells causing recurrent bacterial 
infections. Option A: Platelet storage pool disorder is a disorder of defective platelet granule formation. Option C: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a type of small vessel vasculitis in children and young 
adults. Option D: Hemophilia is a coagulation disorder, hence the platelet count is not affected.

questions.question:
Question 5: Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in patients with which of the following 
conditions?
questions.explanation:
Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in drug-induced thrombocytopenia. Common 
drugs that cause this are quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds. Drug-dependent antibody binding can only be demonstrated in the presence of the drug in the 
laboratory assays. The thrombocytopenia normally occurs within 21 days of initial exposure and 
usually gets resolved after 7-10 days once the drug is stopped. Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in: • Drug-induced thrombocytopenia • Infection-induced thrombocytopenia • Idiopathic/ immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) Option A: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a disorder of platelet adhesion. There are no 
autoantibodies against platelets. Option B: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is an inherited disorder with defective granule formation 
in platelets. It affects platelet activation and aggregation. Option C: Thrombotic microangiopathies like thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and 
hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) lead to thrombocytopenia due to increased platelet 
consumption.

questions.question:
Question 6: A young man comes to you with complaints of bleeding gums and the following skin rash. He 
reports that he had diarrhea last week after eating at a roadside eatery. History is significant 
for deep vein thrombosis 6 months ago that was treated with heparin. His CBC report 
revealed a platelet count of 15,000/µL, normal RBC and WBC count. His peripheral smear 
was normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and image showing petechiae are suggestive of immune 
thrombocytopenic purpura. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder with autoantibodies against 
platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It can either be primary (idiopathic) or 
secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE or infections like HIV and hepatitis C. It presents with features of mucocutaneous bleeding. CBC shows isolated thrombocytopenia and 
peripheral smear does not reveal any hemolysis. Options A and B: HUS and TTP are microangiopathies. They are associated with hemolysis and 
schistocytes on peripheral smear. 1354 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia typically presents within 5-10 days of treatment. 
Hence, it is not the likely diagnosis in this patient. Acute ITP

questions.question:
Question 7: Two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old presents with ecchymosis 
and petechiae all over the body. Abdominal examination revealed no hepatosplenomegaly. 
The platelet count is 15,000/µL and the coagulation profile is normal. Which of the following 
is false regarding this condition?

options.b: Bone marrow biopsy shows increased megakaryocytes
options.c: Bleeding into the joints is a common manifestation
options.d: The condition resolves spontaneously in 80% patients

questions.explanation:
This scenario is suggestive of acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura. Bleeding into the joints is 
seen in coagulation disorders and is not a manifestation of this condition. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired 
disorder in which there is an immune-mediated destruction of platelets. It can be acute or 
chronic. Acute ITP is common in children and is usually preceded by viral infection. It presents with 
mucocutaneous bleeding (epistaxis, petechiae, ecchymosis). Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, 
lymphadenopathy, fever and jaundice are absent. The following laboratory features are seen: • Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000 / L) • Bleeding time - prolonged • PT/aPTT/INR - normal • Bone marrow - normal/increased megakaryocytes • Peripheral smear - normal 1355 
Sold by @itachibot This condition resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases. Treatment is as follows: • Platelet count < 30,000 with risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or 
concomitant bleeding disorders): Oral glucocorticoids or IVIG • Severe bleeding symptoms: IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG • Life-threatening bleeding (like intracranial hemorrhage): platelet transfusion + IV 
methylprednisolone + IVIG

questions.question:
Question 8: A 50-year-old woman comes to the ER after developing a spontaneous nosebleed. Over the 
past 1 week, she has noticed blood on her toothbrush while brushing her teeth. She was 
diagnosed with hepatitis C three months ago. Investigations reveal a platelet count of 32,000/ 
µL and a bleeding time of 9 minutes . Which of the following is false regarding the treatment 
of this patient?

options.a: She requires regular platelet transfusions until platelet count is normalized
options.b: Prednisone or anti-D immunoglobulins can be used as the first-line treatment
options.c: Splenectomy may be done if she relapses after medical management
options.d: Romiplostim and eltrombopag can be used if there is no response to splenectomy

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario in an adult patient is suggestive of chronic ITP (idiopathic thrombocytopenic 
purpura). She does not require platelet transfusion. It is recommended only for patients with 
severe bleeding manifestations (intracranial/ gastrointestinal) or platelet count < 5000 L. Chronic ITP can either be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE 
or infections like HIV and hepatitis C. Depending on the clinical features, the management is as

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following is the best treatment for the relapse of immune thrombocytopenic 
purpura?
questions.explanation:
Splenectomy is the treatment of choice in a case of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) 
relapse after first line therapy with glucocorticoids. The relapse usually occurs once they are 
tapered. Vaccination against encapsulated organisms (pneumococcus, meningococcus, H. 
influenzae) is advised before splenectomy is performed. It is important to note that in some patients ITP resolves by itself, and observation along with 
intermittent IV immunoglobulins and anti - Rh(D) administration or administration of a 1356 
Sold by @itachibot thrombopoietin receptor agonist (eltrombopag, romiplostim) can be a viable option before 
splenectomy is considered. The treatment of ITP is as follows: ITP is an acquired disorder characterized by the immune-mediated destruction of platelets and 
possibly inhibition of platelet release from the megakaryocyte. Secondary causes of ITP include 
systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), HIV-AIDS, and Hepatitis C. ITP usually presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, very low platelet count, and normal 
peripheral blood cells. Patients typically exhibit ecchymoses and petechiae or they may 
incidentally discover thrombocytopenia during a routine complete blood count. Rarely, 
life-threatening bleeding may occur. The presence of wet purpura (blood blisters in the mouth) 
and retinal hemorrhages can serve as warning signs of potentially life-threatening bleeding. Clinical features

questions.question:
Question 10: 1345 
Sold by @itachibot It is your first day as an intern in the medicine ward. The senior resident tells you to check 
the platelet count of a patient who is being monitored for thrombocytopenia. He was started 
on a new medication the previous night. What drug was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Abciximab can cause a drop in platelet count within 24 hours of initial exposure. Hence, these 
patients must be monitored for thrombocytopenia. This is due to naturally-occurring antibodies 
that cross-react with the drug bound to the platelets. Thrombocytopenia due to other drugs typically occurs several days after exposure (average 21 
days) and resolves in 7-10 days after drug withdrawal. Drug-induced thrombocytopenia can occur 
due to the following mechanisms: • Bone marrow suppression - chemotherapeutic drugs • Drug dependent antibodies that react with platelet surface antigens - quinine and sulfonamides • Naturally occurring antibodies that cross-react with drugs bound to the platelets - platelet Gp 
IIb/IIIa inhibitors 1357 
Sold by @itachibot Some of the drugs that cause thrombocytopenia are: • Antibiotics - ampicillin, cephalosporins, piperacillin, vancomycine • Analgesics - ibuprofen, acetaminophen • Anti-epileptics - phenytoin, carbamazepine • Heparin • Amiodarone

questions.question: Question 11: Patients with all of the following usually present with bleeding except:
questions.explanation:
Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is not associated with bleeding. On the contrary, it is 
associated with an increased risk of thrombosis. This condition occurs due to the production of antibodies against the heparin-PF4 complex 
(platelet factor 4, a platelet-specific protein). These antibodies can activate platelets and result in 
thrombosis. It is seen 5-14 days after exposure to heparin. These antibodies can be detected using ELISA or serotonin release assay. This condition is 
managed by discontinuing heparin and using alternative anticoagulants.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following cannot be used in the treatment of patients with heparin-induced 
thrombocytopenia?
questions.explanation:
Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) such as enoxaparin cannot be used in the treatment 
of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). This is because HIT antibodies (against 
anti-PF4-heparin complex) may cross-react with LMWH. HIT can occur following exposure to unfractionated heparin and less commonly with LMWH. The treatment of HIT is as follows: • Discontinue heparin • Anticoagulation with non-heparin anticoagulants even in the absence of thrombosis, since 
there is a high risk of thrombosis. • Direct thrombin inhibitors: Argatroban, lepirudin, bivalirudin • Danaparoid (heparinoid)

questions.question:
Question 13: The CBC of a 33-year-old woman revealed a low platelet count. However, further evaluation 
revealed this to be an in vitro sampling error. Which of the following is the likely cause of this 
finding?
questions.explanation:
This scenario is suggestive of pseudothrombocytopenia. It is seen in blood samples collected with 
EDTA as the anticoagulant. EDTA causes a reduction in the calcium content of the collected blood sample. This triggers in 
vitro platelet clumping and agglutination by antibodies (usually IgG), as shown below: 1358 
Sold by @itachibot When a low platelet count is obtained with an EDTA sample, the peripheral blood smear should 
be evaluated. The platelet count must also be determined in blood collected in sodium citrate or 
heparin collection tubes or fresh fingerstick blood sample.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is false regarding patients with Bernard-Soulier syndrome?

options.a: Platelet aggregation tests with epinephrine and ADP are normal

questions.explanation:
The ristocetin aggregation test is abnormal (no aggregation) in patients with Bernard-Soulier (BS) 
syndrome. It is an inherited disorder of platelet function or qualitative platelet disorder due to deficiency of 
the Gp Ib-IX receptor. This is the platelet membrane receptor for the von Willebrand factor 
(vWF). The binding of the vWF to the GpIb-IX-V complex on the platelet membrane is essential 
for platelet adhesion to the vessel wall. This condition presents with mild thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear shows large platelets. Platelet aggregation tests are performed to measure platelet activation and aggregation in vitro. 
Various platelet agonists like ADP, epinephrine, collagen, and ristocetin can be used to perform 
these tests. In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the following responses are seen: • With ristocetin - No response/no aggregation, as ristocetin specifically binds to the platelet 
membrane via the Gp Ib-IXa receptor • With ADP or epinephrine - Normal response, as Gp IIb-IIIa receptor is not involved in this 
process

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is the most common inherited bleeding disorder?
questions.explanation:
Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. 1359 
Sold by @itachibot vWD occurs due to deficient or abnormal von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is synthesized by 
endothelial cells and megakaryocytes (gene located on chromosome 12p). It is then stored in 
endothelial storage vesicles, Weibel-Palade bodies. Metalloprotease ADAMTS13 cleaves ultra-large 
multimers of VWF which are responsible for platelet adhesion. The functions of vWF and the corresponding symptoms include: • Adhesion of the platelets to the exposed subendothelium - symptoms of both platelet and 
bleeding disorders • Prolongs the half-life of factor VIII by binding to it in circulation - hemophilia A like symptoms 
(rare)

presentation is similar to hemophilia. The types of vWD are: In pseudo vWD, the vWF is normal. However, platelets have an increased affinity for vWF. It

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following patients has Heyde's syndrome?

options.a: A man with aortic stenosis with gastrointestinal bleeding
options.b: A woman with aortic stenosis with intracranial bleed
options.c: A man with aortic regurgitation with gastrointestinal bleeding
options.d: A woman with aortic regurgitation with intracranial bleed

questions.explanation:
Heyde’s syndrome is aortic stenosis with gastrointestinal bleeding, due to angiodysplasia of the 
gastrointestinal tract. The shear stress on blood passing through the stenotic aortic valve produces a change in the von 
Willebrand factor making it susceptible to serum proteases. Hence, large multimer forms are lost, 1360 
Sold by @itachibot leading to an acquired type 2 von Willebrand disease (vWD). The condition is reversed with the 
replacement of the aortic valve. Other causes of acquired vWD include: • Multiple myeloma • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma • Polycythemia vera • Systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following laboratory findings is seen in a patient with von Willebrand's disease?
questions.explanation:
Bleeding time is increased in von Willebrand disease (vWD). It is a combination of a platelet 
adhesion defect with factor VIII deficiency. The laboratory findings in vWD include: • Platelet count is normal (except type 2B) • Bleeding time is prolonged • Ristocetin aggregation is abnormal • Other platelet aggregation tests are normal • Prothrombin time (PT) is normal • aPTT is prolonged • VWF activity is decreased • Factor VIII activity is decreased

questions.question:
Question 19: A 28-year-old woman is being evaluated for prolonged bleeding following a tooth extraction. 
She also reports heavy bleeding during menses and recurrent gum bleeds. Labs show 
increased aPTT, normal PT, and increased bleeding time. Which of the following is the 
first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of von Willebrand's disease. The preferred first-line treatment 
is desmopressin (DDAVP). This drug acts on endothelial V2 receptors causing the release of VWF and factor VIII from 
endothelial stores. DDAVP can be given intravenously or by an intranasal spray. The side effects 
include tachyphylaxis and hyponatremia. VWF concentrate and factor VIII concentrate are reserved for patients with severe disease or prior 
to major procedures. Antifibrinolytic therapy (tranexamic acid or -aminocaproic acid) may be 
used for the prevention and treatment of mucosal bleeding.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following features is not seen in patients with Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia?

options.a: Abnormal platelet aggregation on adding ADP

questions.explanation:
Thrombocytopenia is not seen in Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia. 1361 
Sold by @itachibot Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia is a primary defect of platelet function (aggregation). It occurs due 
to congenital absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor. It presents as superficial mucocutaneous 
bleeding with normal platelet count and single isolated platelets without clumping on peripheral 
smear. The levels of vWF are normal. Normally, release of ADP causes platelets to change shape and bind to fibrinogen through the 
GpIIb/IIIa receptor. In Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, absence of the receptor causes abnormal 
aggregation (absent or reduced) on adding ADP. However, aggregation in response to ristocetin is 
normal, as it is dependent on GpIb and vWF. Secondary platelet dysfunction can be seen in the following conditions: • Uremia • Paraproteinemia • Myeloproliferative disorders

questions.question:
Question 21: A physician decides to start a patient with stroke on antiplatelet medication. All of the 
following drugs would be effective except:
questions.explanation:
Pagoclone is an anxiolytic medication. It is not an antiplatelet drug. The thienopyridine drugs are ADP receptor or P2Y12 antagonists that inhibit ADP mediated 
platelet aggregation. They include the following drugs: • Clopidogrel - commonly used • Ticagrelor - reversible drug with a shorter t1/2, does not require activation, may cause mild, 
self-limited dyspnea • Prasugrel - 10 times more potent than clopidogrel, rapid onset of action, better absorption, more 
predictable • Ticlopidine Clopidogrel and prasugrel are prodrugs that require activation by cytochrome P450 
enzymes. CYP2C19 polymorphisms can cause reduced platelet inhibition with clopidogrel and 
increased risk of cardiovascular events.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 24-year-old woman underwent evaluation for bleeding manifestations and severe anemia. 
Investigations revealed combined autoimmune hemolytic anemia and idiopathic 
thrombocytopenic purpura. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Combined autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) 
is called Evans syndrome. Options B and C: May-Hegglin anomaly and Fechtner syndrome are autosomal dominant 
hereditary conditions presenting with bleeding, sensorineural hearing loss, glomerulonephritis, 
and/or eye abnormalities. The severity of the bleeding symptoms is out of proportion to the 
moderately decreased platelet count. Option D: Rosenthal syndrome or hemophilia C refers to factor XI deficiency. 1362 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 23: What is the most common side effect experienced by patients taking enteric-coated aspirin?
questions.explanation:
The most common side effect of aspirin is gastrointestinal symptoms. The use of enteric-coated 
aspirin does not reduce these side effects. Aspirin irreversibly acetylates and inhibits platelet cyclooxygenase (COX)-1, which causes reduced 
synthesis of thromboxane A2. At high doses, it also inhibits COX-2, which results in the 
anti-inflammatory effects of aspirin. The major GI side effects include dyspepsia, erosive gastritis, peptic ulcers with bleeding and 
perforation. The overall risk of major bleeding with aspirin is 1–3% per year, which increases 2-3 
fold if there is concurrent use of other antiplatelet drugs or anticoagulants. The risk of bleeding 
can be reduced by eradication of Helicobacter pylori infection and giving proton pump inhibitors 
(PPIs). Aspirin sensitivity refers to bronchospasm or urticaria/angioedema seen immediately after 
administration of aspirin. It is also called Samter's triad (asthma, recurrent nasal polyps, aspirin 
sensitivity). In patients with aspirin resistance, there is failure of aspirin to produce its normal 
platelet inhibitory functions.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following is incorrect about the mechanism of action of dipyridamole?

options.a: Increases levels of cyclic AMP in platelets

questions.explanation:
Dipyridamole increases extracellular adenosine levels. It is an antiplatelet drug that increases levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP) in platelets by: • Blocking the reuptake of adenosine and increasing extracellular adenosine levels • Inhibiting phosphodiesterase-mediated cAMP degradation This increase in cyclic AMP reduces intracellular levels of calcium. This inhibits platelet activation 
and aggregation. 1363 
Sold by @itachibot Dipyridamole is a weak antiplatelet used in combination with aspirin for the prevention of stroke 
in patients with TIA. Side effects include gastrointestinal and vasodilatory complaints (headache, flushing, dizziness, 
hypotension). Due to it's vasodilatory effects, it is contraindicated in patients with symptomatic 
coronary artery disease.

questions.question:

intervention. He was diagnosed with diabetic nephropathy 2 months ago. The cardiologist 
decides to start him on aspirin and an additional antiplatelet drug. Which of the following can 
be used for this patient? 1349

Abciximab is safe in patients with renal impairment. It belongs to the group of GpIIb-IIIa receptor 
antagonists. These are parenteral drugs that are used in the management of patients with acute

questions.question: Question 26: Plasmapheresis is the mainstay of treatment in patients with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Plasmapheresis is the mainstay of the treatment of patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic 
purpura (TTP). The best response to this therapy is seen in patients with ADAMTS13 autoantibodies. 
Plasmapheresis is continued until the resolution of platelet count and signs of hemolysis for at 
least 2 days. Option A: The first line of treatment of autoimmune hemolytic anemia is glucocorticoids. The 
second line includes rituximab and splenectomy. Option B: Treatment of disseminated intravascular coagulation is primarily supportive with 
measures to treat the underlying cause. Option D: Treatment of HUS is primarily supportive. Dialysis is usually required. In some varients 
of HUS plasma infusion/exchange can be effective by replasing the complement-regulatory 
proteins. 1364 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 27: Which of the following is not seen in patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.explanation:
Large vessel arterial or venous thromboemboli are not seen in thrombotic thrombocytopenic 
purpura (TTP). This condition is associated with microvascular thrombosis. TTP occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies against the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which 
normally cleaves multimers of vWF. In this condition, the vWF molecules persist causing 
pathogenic platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes localized platelet thrombi and fibrin 
deposits at various sites. It presents with the following pentad of clinical features: • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia - mechanical shearing of RBCs as they pass through platelet 
rich-microthrombi • Thrombocytopenia - deposition of platelets in microthrombi • Renal failure - microthrombi in the renal vasculature • Neurologic findings - headache, confusion, transient focal neurologic deficits • Fever

questions.question:
Question 28: Which of the following is incorrect regarding patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic 
purpura?

options.a: Clinical features overlap with hemolytic uremic syndrome
options.c: It is common in patients with HIV infection
options.d: It can be associated with use of quinine

questions.explanation:
In patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), the PT and aPTT are normal, as 
consumptive coagulopathy is not seen. TTP and HUS are thrombotic microangiopathies with overlapping clinical features. TTP can be 
primary (ADAMTS13 deficiency) or secondary (associated with infections like HIV and drugs like 
quinine). Note: In disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), thrombocytopenia and microangiopathy 
are seen. It is associated with consumption of clotting factors and fibrinogen resulting in 
prolonged PT and aPTT.

questions.question:
Question 29: What is the most common genetic abnormality seen in patients with recurrent history of 
venous thrombosis? 1350 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of venous thrombosis. Venous 
thrombosis typically manifests as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary thromboembolism. Hypercoagulable states or thrombophilias can be inherited or acquired: • Inherited causes in decreasing order of prevalence are as follows: • Factor V Leiden mutation • Prothrombin mutation • Protein C deficiency 1365 
Sold by @itachibot • Protein S deficiency • Antithrombin III deficiency • Acquired causes include: • Surgery • Malignancy • Antiphospholipid syndrome • Trauma • Pregnancy • Long-haul travel • Obesity • Oral contraceptives/hormone replacement • Myeloproliferative disorders • Polycythemia vera

questions.question: Question 30: Which of the following qualitative platelet disorders are inherited as autosomal dominant?
questions.explanation:
Platelet storage pool disease (SPD) is an example of an autosomal dominant qualitative platelet 
disorder. It refers to a group of disorders characterized by a deficiency of platelet granules causing 
secretion defects. Bernard Soulier syndrome, Glanzman thrombasthenia, and Chediak-Higashi syndrome are 
inherited as autosomal recessive traits. 1366 
Sold by @itachibot Acute Leukemia
